scripts.test:e2e: yarn wait-for-datastore-emulator && concurrently -n server,jest --success first --kill-others 'yarn start-test-server' 'wait-on http://localhost:8000 && yarn run-jest-e2e'
scripts.wait-for-datastore-emulator: echo 'Checking that Datastore emulator is ready...' && wait-on --interval 1000 --window 1000 --timeout 120000 http-get://datastore-emulator:8080/

scriptsComments.build: Run tsc to transpile source, result in `dist` directory. Copy env files there too (functions emulator and prod will need them).
scriptsComments.run-jest-e2e: Run the end-to-end test suite with Jest, but doesn't do any setup (like building or starting dev servers). See `test:e2e` script
scriptsComments.start-dev-server: Start the server (via Google's Functions Framework) in the development environment
scriptsComments.start-functions-framework: Emulate Google Cloud Functions, running the 'blessing' request handler in index.ts from an HTTP server. It will only look for an `index.js` file in the current directory, so we have to cd into the `dist` directory before starting it. Dumb. Requires project to have been built/transpiled previously (since it expects JS, not TS).
scriptsComments.start-test-server: Start the server (via Google's Functions Framework) in the test environment
scriptsComments.test:e2e: Starts the dev/test server and runs the end-to-end test suite. Needs the (dockerized) Datastore emulator to be running.
scriptsComments.test:integration: Runs integration tests (whose names end in *.itest.ts). Needs the (dockerized) Datastore emulator to be running.
scriptsComments.wait-for-datastore-emulator: Checks that the Datastore emulator has been started (probably via `docker-compose up`). We could just start the emulator ourselves in whatever scripts require it, but that might cause problems in Google's CI tool.
